ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Grammar skills: continued to work on subjonctive, imperfect and various tenses. Grammar focused as well on idioms and writing. 

this course focused provides a muched more balanced review of reading/literature and grammar than 130.
The course gave students a strong foundation in writing, grammar, and oral speaking skills
I learned brand new grammar I'd never seen before in high school, which was refreshing if a challenge.
I solidified a lot of the grammar I learned in high school. I also learned how to read French novels because they taught the pass simple. My speaking and listening also improved

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: engaging readings and Prof. Koundi is truly amazing. 

Weaknesses: the course packet is very unhelpful for learning grammar.
The course was very well structured towards facilitating student learning and highly engaging. The texts discussed in this French course in particular are really fascinating and engaging too!

Strength: we read some challenging full-length books and critically acclaimed post-colonial short stories by francophone writers, which makes the reading interesting and rewarding to have achieved this level of proficiency. 

Weakness: we do not practice speaking very much
Not of the assigned audio homeworks were very effective. A lot of them were very long and since it was a call and response type of thing, they felt a little unnecessary to do

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but be prepared to have a good amount of work.
Yes! I absolutely would recommend this course for students looking to further develop their French skills

Yes, if you enjoy classroom French learning, participate a lot (Professor Koundi doesn't favor shy students) and don't mind writing literary analysis for the Rdactions. The workload of this class is VERY high. The professor claimed it would be less than in L3 but this time you actually need to do all of it. That being said, we learn a lot of new grammar and read some interesting/challenging literature.
